'Friday Night Lights' creator developing TV pilot based on Levittown high school theater program   5:47 PM EST 18 Share Molly Eichel Staff Writer 
Molly Eichel is an assistant features editor. She writes about film and television, and edits the Weekend section. Molly was born and raised in Philadelphia, where she spent a lot of time sitting too close to the television screen. More by Molly Eichel 
Jason Katims, the mind behind the TV adaptations of Parenthood and Friday Night Lights , and Hamilton producer Jeffery Seller have teamed up for a TV pilot with local ties. The duo will adapt Drama High: The Incredible True Story of a Brilliant Teacher , written by former Inquirer and Daily News reporter Michael Sokolove in 2013. The book dives deep into theater program at Levittown's Harry S. Truman High School when it was run by Lou Volpe, who retired from the school in 2013 
NBC has ordered a pilot, according to Variety 
Sokolove is a product of Volpe's theater program. He's not the only famous alum: Former CBS3 anchor Susan Barnett, Kim Possible creator and noted children's screenwriter Bob Schooley, and countless artists and arts educators came under Volpe's tutelage. 
"Everybody likes to have something on TV and all of the things that comes with that," said Sokolove, who is now based in Washington, D.C. and is longtime contributor to the New York Times magazine. "It's an honor. A producer of Hamilton 
The book centers on Volpe, contrasting his passion for the arts — he tested many major musicals, including Les Miserables , Rent and Spring Awakening , for the high school stage —th the blue-collar Levittown setting. 
Sokolove was quick to mention that the pilot is simply based off his book and will ultimately be fiction. It will likely not be set in Levittown, but in a similar place. "[
